Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA, formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, given no direct relation, but considering a broad differential)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can damage any part of the body, including skin, joints, and/or organs inside the body.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever, affecting the heart, joints, skin, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection spread by ticks, characterized by a rash, fever, headache, and muscle pain.

diagnoses.name: Meningococcemia
diagnoses.description: A severe infection in the bloodstream caused by the Neisseria meningitidis bacteria, potentially leading to meningitis and other forms of meningococcal disease.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the small blood vessels causing rashes, joint pain, abdominal pain, and kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels, causing changes in the walls of blood vessels, including thickening, weakening, narrowing, and scarring.

diagnoses.name: Serum Sickness
diagnoses.description: A reaction similar to an allergy. It occurs when the immune system reacts to certain medications, or to the venom in a bee sting.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections, often associated with tampon use, surgical wounds, or skin infections.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus, a virus that attacks the immune system. If not treated, it can lead to AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome).

diagnoses.name: Acute Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the kidneys that occurs after infection with certain strains of Streptococcus bacteria.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems in the body, causing a wide range of symptoms including autoimmune hemolysis, acute pericarditis, nephritis (seen as lupus nephritis), seizures, and neuropsychiatric manifestations such as delirium.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder is characterized by thrombosis and pregnancy-related complications, but it can also lead to hemolytic anemia, seizures, possible cardiac complications like pericarditis, and occasional kidney involvement. Cognitive impairments or acute confusional states can mimic delirium.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Although best known for affecting the joints, severe and longstanding rheumatoid arthritis can have systemic manifestations including pericarditis, renal involvement, and neurological symptoms such as seizures or severe cognitive dysfunction, although autoimmune hemolysis is less common.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease shares characteristics of various connective tissue diseases including SLE. It can present with features such as nephritis, pericarditis, and neurological symptoms. Hematological manifestations like hemolytic anemia can occur.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects the exocrine glands, but systemic involvement can lead to kidney disease (interstitial nephritis), central nervous system effects including seizures and neuropathies, and pericarditis. Hemolytic anemia is less common but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This systemic vasculitis can cause a wide range of symptoms including central nervous system involvement leading to seizures, vascular complications which might mimic hematological disorders, and rare reports of renal involvement and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: A systemic granulomatous disease that can affect multiple organs including the nervous system (neuro-sarcoidosis, which can manifest as seizures), heart (pericarditis), and kidneys (nephritis). Hemolytic anemia is rare but possible.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Encompasses a group of diseases that can cause widespread organ involvement due to blood vessel inflammation. Conditions such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis or Microscopic Polyangiitis may cause renal, neurological, and rare cardiac symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily an infection of the heart valves, infectious endocarditis can lead to a variety of systemic symptoms, including renal involvement, immune-mediated hemolytic anemia, and rare complications such as seizures or acute confusional states.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hepatitis
diagnoses.rationale: This liver disease can sometimes be associated with other systemic autoimmune disorders that could indirectly cause or exacerbate symptoms like autoimmune hemolysis, pericarditis, renal involvement, and neurological symptoms including confusion or rare seizure instances.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C with cryoglobulinemia
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis)

diagnoses.rationale: Connective tissue disorder that may link symptoms of easy bleeding, dysphagia, and vascular anomalies.
Bleeding disorder that could cause easy bleeding and is sometimes associated with gastrointestinal symptoms like constipation.
Presence of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus can cause chronic pelvic pain and might be linked indirectly to gastrointestinal symptoms like constipation.
Genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation and could account for easy bleeding and vascular anomalies.
Though rare, these tumors can cause dysphagia and constipation, and in some cases, might be associated with systemic syndromes that include vascular anomalies.
Autoimmune disorder that can cause gastrointestinal symptoms like dysphagia and constipation and may have vascular elements due to malabsorption.
Connective tissue disease that can cause dysphagia due to esophageal involvement, constipation from intestinal involvement, and vascular symptoms.
Genetic disorder affecting connective tissue and could possibly link to vascular anomalies, though less directly to the other symptoms.
Systemic lupus erythematosus can cause a wide range of symptoms including those related to vascular integrity and gastrointestinal issues.
Inflammatory bowel disease that primarily causes digestive system symptoms but can also be associated with vascular problems through inflammation and other systemic effects.
Bronchitis, especially chronic bronchitis, is a key component of COPD. Patients may go through poor healing due to decreased oxygenation and systemic effects.
Poor healing is a hallmark of diabetes, which can also cause abnormal electrolytes due to the osmotic diuresis prompted by hyperglycemia. Flushing could be related to autonomic neuropathy.
These can present with a wide array of symptoms, including abnormal electrolyte balance, flushing, and poor healing. Interstitial cystitis has been associated with autoimmune diseases.
Abnormal electrolytes are a common feature due to the impaired filtration functions. The disease's impact might also contribute to symptoms like poor healing.
This condition can lead to poor healing, abnormal electrolytes, and flushing due to the excessive cortisol levels.

Can contribute to poor healing, and may sometimes be associated with imbalances in electrolytes. Although less directly related to flushing and interstitial cystitis, systemic effects might influence these symptoms.

This rare tumor can cause flushing and abnormal electrolytes due to catecholamine release. Though not directly linked to poor healing or interstitial cystitis, the systemic effects might contribute to the symptom complex.

An autoimmune disease that can present with systemic features affecting multiple organs, potentially explaining the combination of symptoms. Interstitial cystitis has been associated with Sjögren's Syndrome.
While primarily affecting the lungs and possibly including bronchitis in its symptomatology, systemic involvement could possibly account for electrolyte imbalances and poor healing.
This disorder of the renal tubules can lead to abnormal electrolytes and might indirectly contribute to the syndrome complex through systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Stress-Related Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is often triggered by severe emotional or physical stress. Stress can also exacerbate or lead to symptoms of hyperactivity and non-restorative sleep.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Some autoimmune disorders can cause skin manifestations like dyshidrotic eczema and may also contribute to systemic issues like monocytosis.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Chronic inflammation can lead to elevated monocyte counts and skin conditions such as dyshidrotic eczema. Stress and poor sleep may exacerbate these conditions.

diagnoses.name: Psychological Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Conditions like anxiety and depression can lead to hyperactivity, non-restorative sleep, and stress that could potentially trigger takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Diseases
diagnoses.rationale: Certain chronic or acute infections can lead to monocytosis and may indirectly cause stress or poor sleep quality due to the body's inflammatory response.

diagnoses.name: Endocrine Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Thyroid dysfunction, for example, can cause hyperactivity, non-restorative sleep, and skin changes, though it is less commonly associated with takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Hematologic Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Some blood diseases lead to monocytosis and may have indirect relationships with stress-related conditions such as takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Cardiac Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Besides takotsubo cardiomyopathy, other heart conditions can be exacerbated by stress, poor sleep, and systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Conditions like diabetes or metabolic syndrome can contribute to chronic inflammation, skin issues like eczema, and are risk factors for cardiac issues.

diagnoses.name: Substance Use Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Excessive use of substances (e.g., alcohol, stimulants) can lead to hyperactivity, non-restorative sleep, skin issues, stress, and potentially even takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Oral Cavity

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.description: Depression
diagnoses.comments: Mood disorder characterized by persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. Contributes to difficulty concentrating, among others.

diagnoses.description: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.comments: A more severe form of depression, includes episodes of severe depression.

diagnoses.description: Dyshidrotic Eczema
diagnoses.comments: Skin condition marked by small, itchy blisters on the edges of the fingers, toes, palms, and soles of the feet.

diagnoses.description: Chronic Idiopathic Angioedema
diagnoses.comments: Condition characterized by recurrent episodes of severe swelling. The cause is unknown.

diagnoses.description: Osteomalacia
diagnoses.comments: Softening of the bones due to a lack of vitamin D or problems with its metabolism. May present with bone pain.

diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.comments: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues.

diagnoses.description: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.comments: A cancer that forms in a type of white blood cell called a plasma cell, causing bone pain and damage.

diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.comments: Condition where the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone. Can cause depression and difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.description: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.comments: Condition involving the overactivity of the parathyroid glands, can lead to osteoporosis and bone pain.

diagnoses.description: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.comments: Can cause bone pain due to decreased calcium absorption, and has been linked to depression.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.reason: Direct match with patient's symptom, potentially linked with weight gain.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Symptoms include weight gain and potential for lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reason: Symptoms can include lymphadenopathy and, in some cases, can cause weight gain due to metabolic changes.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Symptoms include weight gain and can lead to obstructive sleep apnea due to weight changes. Hypothyroidism can also affect metabolism, contributing to malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Some types linked with POTS, and it can indirectly affect digestive system leading to malabsorption issues.

diagnoses.name: Cardiac insufficiency
diagnoses.reason: While not directly causing all symptoms, can be related to POTS and lead to symptom exacerbation like weight gain due to reduced activity.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Disorders (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Celiac Disease)
diagnoses.reason: These conditions can cause malabsorption and could indirectly influence weight changes. Might also impact general health, contributing to conditions like obstructive sleep apnea.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Overlaps with POTS in symptomology and can influence weight gain due to reduced activity levels.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1
diagnoses.reason: It can present with tumors that affect hormone levels, leading to symptoms like weight gain and malabsorption, and possibly involve lymph node enlargement.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Gastroenteritis
diagnoses.description: A rare disease affecting the digestive system with eosinophilic infiltration, potentially linking gastrointestinal symptoms and allergic manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Reactive Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that develops in response to an infection in another part of the body (cross-reactivity), manifesting with arthritis, eye irritation, and sometimes skin problems.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and other parts of the body, potentially explaining the irritated eyes and could secondarily affect the gastrointestinal tract.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, a rare autoimmune disorder characterized by widespread inflammation in the walls of small blood vessels (vasculitis), potentially linking basophilia, respiratory and gastrointestinal issues.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder characterized by high counts of eosinophils, which could manifest through various organ dysfunctions including gastrointestinal tract and possibly link to other reported symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, potentially explaining gastrointestinal symptoms and secondary effects like osteopenia due to malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition affecting the digestive system where stomach acid flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach (esophagus), which can indirectly affect esophageal motility and possibly contribute to gastroparesis symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hyper-IgE Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare immunodeficiency characterized by high levels of a particular antibody, leading to recurrent skin and lung infections and possibly linking to elevated eosinophil counts.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Granulomatous Disease
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the immune system's ability to fight certain infections, potentially explaining multiple systemic symptoms including those related to infections like otitis media.

diagnoses.name: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding, resulting from unusually low levels of platelets. This syndrome sometimes associates with autoimmune disorders and could indirectly relate to the combination of symptoms through autoimmune dysregulation.

diagnoses.name: Atopic dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A condition that makes your skin red and itchy. It's common in children but can occur at any age. Atopic dermatitis is long-lasting (chronic) and tends to flare periodically. It may be accompanied by asthma or hay fever.

diagnoses.name: Contact dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A skin rash caused by contact with a certain substance. The substances may cause the skin to become red, swollen, blistering, dry, bumpy, and itchy, depending on the substance and the individual's sensitivity.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A skin disease that causes red, itchy scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk, and scalp. Psoriasis is a chronic disease that often comes and goes.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. SLE can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing inflammation in blood vessels throughout your body. The condition often leads to mouth sores, genital sores, eye problems, and skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Cellulitis
diagnoses.description: A common and potentially serious bacterial skin infection. The affected skin appears swollen and red and is typically painful and warm to the touch.

diagnoses.name: Herpetic whitlow
diagnoses.description: A viral infection of the finger with the herpes simplex virus. It causes painful wounds on the fingers or around the nails.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV damages the immune system and hinders the body's ability to fight the organisms that cause disease. AIDS is the most advanced stage of HIV infection.

diagnoses.name: Secondary syphilis
diagnoses.description: The second stage of syphilis, featuring symptoms including skin rash, fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes. These symptoms can be mild and come and go for up to three years.

diagnoses.name: Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A rare type of cancer that begins in the white blood cells and attacks the skin, causing rashes, plaques, and tumors. It is a form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms but is frequently associated with headaches, photophobia, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.details: An inflammation of the fluid and membranes surrounding your brain and spinal cord, often leading to symptoms like headache, fever, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.details: Severe, one-sided headaches that can cause photophobia and occasional nausea, typically occurring in groups or clusters.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
diagnoses.details: Bleeding in the space between the brain and the surrounding membrane, severe sudden onset headache is a common symptom along with vomiting and light sensitivity.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: Tumors in the brain can present with headache, nausea/vomiting, and sensitivity to light due to increased intracranial pressure among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.details: Inflammation of the brain, often caused by an infection. Symptoms include headache, photophobia, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Glaucoma
diagnoses.details: An eye condition that can lead to blindness if not treated, characterized by high eye pressure which can cause photophobia, as well as severe headaches and vomiting in acute cases.

diagnoses.name: Sinusitis
diagnoses.details: Inflammation of the sinuses, can cause headache, photophobia due to the pressure in the sinuses, and sometimes nausea.

diagnoses.name: Pseudotumor Cerebri
diagnoses.details: Also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension, this condition mimics the symptoms of a brain tumor including headaches, vision problems, nausea, and photophobia without an actual tumor being present.

diagnoses.name: Heat Stroke
diagnoses.details: A condition caused by your body overheating, usually as a result of prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures. This can lead to headache, nausea, and sensitivity to light among other symptoms.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Hepatitis B or C with associated cryoglobulinemia
Perniose (not in the context of lupus)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can cause a broad range of symptoms including hemolytic anemia, synovitis (inflammation of the joint linings), nonscarring alopecia, and neuropsychiatric manifestations such as delirium.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis with Felty's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Felty's Syndrome, associated with rheumatoid arthritis, can lead to hemolytic anemia and synovitis. Though less commonly, it can also cause alopecia and delirium due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain medications can induce a lupus-like syndrome with symptoms such as hemolytic anemia, synovitis, nonscarring alopecia, and neurological symptoms including delirium.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including hemolytic anemia and neurological manifestations such as delirium. While less commonly associated with synovitis and alopecia, they can occur.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affecting the body's moisture-producing glands, Sjögren's Syndrome can also lead to systemic issues such as hemolytic anemia and nonscarring alopecia. Joint symptoms and neurological manifestations are less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A rare autoimmune disorder that involves hemolytic anemia and can lead to other autoimmune symptoms, which might mimic the presented symptom combination.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD features a mixture of symptoms from different diseases including lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, and can include hemolytic anemia, synovitis, alopecia, and neuropsychiatric symptoms such as delirium.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Various forms of vasculitis can cause a broad symptom range including hemolytic anemia, neurological issues (e.g., delirium), and, in some cases, can affect the joints and hair follicles.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Although less common, severe thyroid diseases can lead to a wide variety of symptoms including hemolytic anemia, alopecia, and, rarely, delirium or neuropsychiatric manifestations. Joint pain or swelling is less typical but can occur in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: In advanced stages, HIV can cause a wide range of symptoms due to its immunosuppressive nature, including hemolytic anemia, joint issues (synovitis), alopecia, and neurological manifestations such as delirium.

diagnoses: Vasculitis secondary to infections (e.g., Hepatitis C)
